results.title: The Hoffnung symphony orchestra [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Harold Whitaker, John Halas, BBC-TV and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Hoffnung”.
A light hearted look at the various instruments of the orchestra, based on the original cartoons of the late Gerard Hoffnung, satirising musical pomposity. The music was composed and conducted by Francis Chagrin, who collaborated with Hoffnung on many occasions.

results.title: The Hoffnung Palm Court Orchestra
results.creator_credit: John Halas, British Broadcasting Corporation and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Hoffnung”.
It is the late 19th century in the lounge of an expensive hotel, where the Palm Court Orchestra is playing to a tea drinking audience. A fire starts and the hotel is soon ablaze, the people flee, but the orchestra plays on. In a series of other situations the orchestra also plays on. Based on a series of cartoon drawings by Gerard Hoffnung.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas, British Broadcasting Corporation and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: The Hoffnung music academy
results.creator_credit: John Halas, British Broadcasting Corporation and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Hoffnung”.
When the music professor rings his bell for his pupils, we take a trip round his Academy to see the various departments in action, including the piano deparment, folk music, military department and church music. Animated film based on the cartoon drawings of Gerard Hoffnung.

results.title: The Hoffnung maestro
results.creator_credit: Harold Whitaker, John Halas, BBC Enterprises and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Hoffnung”.
As the maestro conducts, a series of characters and situations express the varying moods of the music. Based on the drawings by Gerard Hoffnung. Credits include: storyboard and design by Tom Bailey; sound by Jack King; animation by Harold Whitaker and music by Francis Chagrin.

results.title: The History of writing
results.brief_description: Divided into four parts. Discusses and illustrates the origins of picture writing; the writing systems of China, Mesopotamia, and Egypt; the emergence of the first real alphabet in Palestine and Syria; the spread of this alphabet to Greece and Rome; and the development of the Roman script through the Middle Ages until the invention of printing.
results.description: Divided into four parts. Discusses and illustrates the origins of picture writing; the writing systems of China, Mesopotamia, and Egypt; the emergence of the first real alphabet in Palestine and Syria; the spread of this alphabet to Greece and Rome; and the development of the Roman script through the Middle Ages until the invention of printing.

results.title: The History of Totalitarianism
results.brief_description: Images are flashed in rapid succession of tyrants, artefacts and symbols of oppression from the days of Cheops to the present, to portray a quick history of man’s oppression of man. A musical score of contrasting rhythms underscores the philosophical message. Without narration.

results.title: The History of the world in three minutes flat
results.creator_credit: Michael Mills and Michael Mills Productions
results.brief_description: Uses vignettes from the past and animators’ licence to provide a humorous account of history as seen through the eyes of “The Creator”. With animation by Jim Hiltz, Bill Speers, Rick Bowman and John Gaug.

results.title: The History of the helicopter
results.creator_credit: Sarah Erulkar and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The growth of vertical flight from the early experiments of Leonardo da Vinci and others to the development of the modern helicopter. A feature of the film is a sequence made up of extracts from early newsreels.
